data.title: Requiem for a great version: "Jambalaya"
data.text:
Post by Jimbo

Post by y***@yahoo.com

Although this didn't make it out of previous round, I think the flip-

side

"You Belong To Me" Columbia 39811, and "Jambalaya" Columbia 39838, were

two separate records. The flip side of "Jambalaya" is "Early Autumn",

another song which made the top 40.

Jim

Post by y***@yahoo.com

http://youtu.be/2boHCNfbUD4

In fact (of opinion here), for my money, this is the best of a slew of

other people's versions of famed songs from the Hank Williams'

songbook, with the possible exception on some days for me of B.J.

Thomas & The Triumphs' heavily-rotated big impact hit of "I'm So

Lonesome I Could Cry" from '66 in the next decade. With any kind of

foresight, Miller and/or Stafford would have held this out to be its

own A-sided hit. U.S. radio, even non-Country stations, played the

Stafford under-card anyway, even decades later on nostalgia radio

formats.

However, although it doesn't trump Hank Williams original, it trumps

many other A-side pop hits of other songs from other artists from

1952, and provided a cheery, upbeat radio presence years after

whenever it was played in Philadelphia; the product of good work by

not just Jo Stafford, but the talent arranger and musicians

participating in this session. Pardon any resemblance to Uni-ism,

but this one truly inspires me a lot, to say: "Good work, Jo!"- Hide quoted text -

- Show quoted text -

Thanks for the correction - it is true I really started looking back

Post by y***@yahoo.com

Post by y***@yahoo.com

Although this didn't make it out of previous round, I think the flip-

side

<Snip>

Post by y***@yahoo.com

Thanks for the correction - it is true I really started looking back

at what was behind (read: before) the mid-50's R&R surge only aoout 20

years ago, but we were well into the CD age by then, and although I

have a nice CD collection combining originals of Jo's Capitol &

Columbia (I THINK those were her labels) stuff, plus having her

elsewhere on various artists collections, the main CD doesn't list

discography details - revealing my slack research or untrustworthy on-

line source here, when I shouldn't, and ought to have gone to the

great discography page that exists, which I had visited before when

researching years for my Swing Era List at Digital Dream Door. If

you're picking up that I never owned the 45 out of that, you're

correct; I don't collect for nostalgia, my time, money and intense

other interests don't allow for every collector's whim, so I just try

to collect the music necessary for myself - usually on CD, but buy any

means necessary - even if it means going back to 10" lps or settling

for cassettes for O.O.P. items - finding one's preferred music is

quite a reach in itself. After two robberies in my lifetime, which

cleaned out my record collections all vinyl before; I'm on my 3rd

collection adventures.

The recordings she made with Tommy Dorsey are also excellent. "You

Belong to Me" and "Jambalaya" were among the very first 45's I

purchased. Her version of "Early Autumn" is one of my favorites.

She did a series of comedy records with husband Paul Weston. If you

have a chance list to the "Darlene and Jonathan Edwards" LP's. Jo was

known for having perfect pitch and she was able to use that ability to

make some wonderful comedy.

Jim
